back: An object will remain at rest, or continue to move with a constant velocity, unless acted on by a resultant force.
The resultant force is directly proportional to the rate of change of momentum, in some direction.
For every force applied to object A by object B, there will be an equal but opposite force applied to object B by object A.

front: What are the characteristics of a pair of forces described by Newton's third law?
back:
• Acting with the same magnitude.
  • Acting in opposite directions.
  • Acting on different objects.
  • Acting as the same type of force.
  • Acting for the same period of time.
Linear momentum is the product of an object's mass and linear velocity.

front: What is the definition of impulse?
back: Impulse is defined as the product of force and the duration of time that the force lasts for.

front: How does Newton's second law lead to the existence of impulse?
back:
Force is rate of change of momentum.
F = Δp/Δt
FΔt = Δp = impulse

front: How can you find the impulse from a force-time graph?
back: Impulse is the area beneath a force-time graph. You could find using calculations, counting squares, or trap rule.

front: What is the principle of the conservation of momentum?
back: The total momentum in a closed system in any direction will always remain constant, as long as no external forces act on the system.

front: What are the different types of collisions?
back:
• Elastic collision - all kinetic energy is conserved.
  • Inelastic collision - some of the kinetic energy is lost.
  • Completely inelastic collision - the maximum amount of kinetic energy is lost (objects coalesce)
  • Superelastic collision - the kinetic energy increases due to external factors.

front: What are some facts that are true for all collisions?
back:
• Total momentum is the same before and after.
  • The magnitude of the impulse / force applied to each object is the same.
  • The total energy in the system is conserved (when including all forms of energy).

front: How do you work out the result of collisions in 2D?
back:
• Resolve for momentum in x and y axes.
  • Momentum is conserved in all directions, so you can equate momentum in both axes before and after the collision.
  • Then, solve for unknowns.
